msContents.summary: Pp 4-13: Charm against the evil eye and against evil spirits invoking John 1:1-5; Pp. 15-22: Another charm whose title is illegible, but seems intended to ward off evils that might come from unjust judges. Pp. 23-25: A charm against the evil eye. Pp. 26-30: A charm "against any sort of eviel from a wicked sinner". Pp. 31-33: A charm whose title is illegible, but is apparently against night mares or evil phantasms.; Pp. 33-37: A charm against any kind of fever. Pp. 37-42: A charm against a throbbing of the head. Pp. 43-50: A spell against a thief. Pp. 50-52: A spell against (evil) tongues, consisting of magical words. Pp. 53-60: The Ban of Mar 'Abdiso' against evil spirits, together with the tale of how the saint got rid of an evil spirit in the form of an ugly woman. Pp. 60-61: A spell against scorpions. Pp. 63-66: A protective charm for a journey. Pp. 66-69: A charm "to obtain favor from everyone." Pp. 70-72: A spell against demons. Pp. 72-76: A spell against snakes. Pp. 77-79: A charm for "rezqa w-bazar w-mamellta" (words not in the Thesaurus syriacus of R. Payne Smith, but, judging by 23 below, designating riches; --the word rezqa is clearly from Arabic rizq, "sustenance"). The text of the charm is largely illegible. Pp. 80-83: A spell to ward off diseases from sheep. Pp. 83-85: A charm against the plague, by the prayer of Mary Zay'a. Pp. 86-91: A love charm. Pp. 93-95: A spell against dogs. Pp. 96-100: A spell against serta (a word not in the Thesaurus, but apparently an affliction of wivs preventing them from giving birth). Pp. 100bis-110: A charm for riches. Pp. 111-121: A concluding prayer invoking the assistance of a long list of saints, including the three Greek Fathers, Theodore (of Mopsuestia), Diodorus and Nestorius, called the an of Paradise. Crude designs and pictures, pp. 1-13, 14, 22, 54, 62, 76, 88, 100, 122-124. (Macomber, Catalogue).
